Award.AwardTitle: Planning Visit Proposal in Support for High Performance Computing for Econometrics Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Planning Visit Proposal in Support for High Performance Computing for Econometrics Applications

The objective of the planning visit is to establish a collaborative research program in the multidisciplinary area of econometrics and high performance computing. Unlike scientific computing which has been mostly the focus of parallel computing, the econometrics area does not get much attention by computer scientists. As part of this planning visit, we will identify what are the major computational challenges in the econometrics domain and how computer science and high performance computing can help in addressing these challenges.

Lack of software to use large scale computing power for econometrics applications has forced researchers to make either some approximations in quantitative analysis of economics data or not fully validate the theories they develop to explain an economic phenomena. Developing tools and libraries that help researchers in the area of econometrics to use massively parallel computing power will enable them to make basic science advances in econometrics that were not possible otherwise. The outcome of this planning visit would be a proposal in this area to NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unlike scientific computing which has been mostly the focus of parallel computing, the econometrics area does not get much attention by computer scientists. One major reason is that it is difficult to find collaborators in econometrics area who are interested in parallel computing.  This planning grant enabled the two researchers in two continents to establish collaboration in a multidisciplinary area of high performance computing and econometrics. The PI on this grant who specializes in the area of high performance computing spent four weeks at the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona, Spain, where he collaborated with Prof. Michael Creel who specializes in econometrics and has interest in parallel computing.  We identified the major computational challenges in the econometrics domain and how computer science and high performance computing in particular can help in addressing these challenges. The intellectual merit of the work we have started is the use of massively parallel computing in making basic science advances in econometrics, which were not possible otherwise. Lack of software to use large scale computing power for econometrics applications has forced researchers to make either  some approximations in quantitative analysis of economics data or not  fully validate the theories they develop to explain an economic phenomena. The objective of this collaboration is to develop library and tools that are easy to use for social scientists and can harness the massive computing power of many cores hardware.  We explored a number of econometrics applications and extracted out a common set of computation intensive kernels.  We explored implementation of few of these kernels on new architectures like GPU. More specifically,  we implemented the major components of a continuous time stochastic volatility model on a GPU. The stochastic volatility model contains all of the following elements: non-constant drift, leverage, jumps with dynamic jump intensity, and measurement error. We also designed projects around these kernels, where undergraduate and graduate students can be involved.  The PI is developing a new graduate course, where he plans to focus application of high performance computing in the area of econometrics.  Based on the outcome of this collaboration, we also plan to write a proposal to NSF.
